An invitation, the Comity was sure, which the Tr'en would not accept.
Korvin stretched out on the cell's single bunk, a rigid affair which was hardly meant for comfort, and sighed. Facts: In June 2019, the US Supreme Court ruled that Louisiana's admitting privilege abortion law, which required abortion providers to have admitting privileges at local hospitals, was unconstitutional because it created a substantial obstacle to access.
Assessment: The claim is correct, since the Supreme Court ruled in favor of abortion rights in that case.
Explanation: On June 28, 2019, the US Supreme Court made a ruling regarding Louisiana's admitting privilege abortion law. Admission privilege laws require abortion providers to have admitting privileges at local hospitals in case of emergencies. These laws increase the financial and legal hurdles providers have to face and can cause closures.
The case involved June Medical Services v. Russo (2019). The 5-4 decision states “Our decision today requires the State to treat abortion providers equally. The State may not refuse to treat Dr. June’s Clinic as a medical facility; and it may not discriminate among providers by imposing a burden that applies to “every other similar medical procedure performed at similarly situated hospitals.'” The court also writes that the law represents “a substantial obstacle” to women’s right to access abortion, since it created a financial and legal barrier to access, particularly for rural women.
This ruling is important in the context of abortion laws as it is the first time the Supreme Court upheld the legitimacy of abortion laws in the post-Dobbs era, which overturned Roe v. Wade.

Elie Wiesel
(born September 30, 1928) is a Romanian-born American memoir writer and Holocaust survivor. The author of more than 50 books, Wiesel's writings include novels, memoirs, and works of non-fiction. He received the Nobel Prize for Peace in 1986 and accepted the award in the name of the six million Jews who were killed during the Holocaust.
Wiesel was born and raised in Transylvania, to a Hasidic Jewish family. As a teenager, Wiesel was deported with his family to Auschwitz and Buchenwald concentration camps. Upon arriving in the United States in 1956, Wiesel completed his schooling at the Sorbonne and at the Jewish Theological Seminary. He would later join the Columbia University faculty where he would be the University's first Andres S.

Institutional Review Board Policy
February 18, 2023
Institutional Research Board (IRB) Policy
The Human Subjects Institutional Review Board (IRB) is established in compliance with Federal regulations governing biomedical and social-behavioral research conducted by institutions receiving support from the US Public Health Services (PHS). The IRB reviews research protocols involving either non-consented clinical investigation or proposed research involving human subjects to verify that the rights and welfare of human subjects are protected. The IRB assures that risks are minimized and are reasonable in relation to anticipated benefits, and that selection of research subjects involves equitable practices. The IRB also assures informed consent in all aspects. 
The Board will monitor that any non-consented research and research involving human subjects, adhere to state law and the Code of Ethical Principles.
IRB MEMBERSHIP AND OPERATIONS
All reviews are completed by the IRB on a case by case basis. All reviews are conducted on an expedited, ad hoc basis. Researchers are required to contact the IRB to discuss their protocol before they begin their data collection. The IRB has regular meetings only when necessary.
STEPS TO COMMENCE A STUDY
A researcher interested in conducting human subject research must have a study protocol reviewed by an IRB member(s) in advance of commencing data collection. The primary IRB contact person will arrange a meeting with the researcher at a time which is suitable for the researcher, to discuss their protocol and submit their protocol for review.
After the initial meeting has taken place the study protocol is sent to reviewers and the IRB members will conduct an initial review of the protocol. An expedited review is completed in order to make a final decision. 
The researcher(s) is asked to address any comments by reviewers before the IRB makes a final decision on the study protocol. If the reviewers raise any issues which are not easily resolved, the IRB members will discuss these issues at that meeting and give a final decision on the protocol.
Once the study protocol is approved the primary IRB contact will provide approval letter(s) to the researcher(s).
DOI OF POLICY
The IRB policy is available electronically

The Absurdity of Family Love
Don't get me wrong. Kids are

great. I have some, and I adore them. Every Christmas I become a slave to my
camcorder. Tiny tots with their eyes all aglow, and so on. But now that the
radiance of the yuletide season is fading, it's time to confront a sobering
scientific truth: The more you think about the biology of parental love, the
more absurd it seems. The same goes for love of kin generally--brothers, sisters,
nephews, etc.
Readers familiar with my obsessions may fear that this column is just another attempt to spoil everyone's fun, to replace the beautiful mystery of life with ugly Darwinian clarity. Actually, what I hope to dispel isn't pre-Darwinian mystery, but a kind of post-Darwinian mysticism, a confused exaltation of genetic affinity. You see the confusion when biological parents invoke "blood ties" to reclaim a child from adoptive parents. You see it when opponents of cross-ethnic adoption argue -- as in a New York Times op-ed piece a few months ago -- that we must respect "the strength of the biological and cultural ties that Indian tribes can offer their own children." In a sense, you see it every year around Christmas, when people pay lip service to the idea of universal brotherhood but believe in their hearts that it's ridiculous, that truly loving people to whom you aren't related violates some law of nature.
Thanks to the biologist William Hamilton

Question: What is the author trying to explain?
[\INST]The Absurdity of Family Love Don't get me wrong. Kids are great. I have some, and I adore them. Every Christmas I become a slave to my camcorder. Tiny tots with their eyes all aglow, and so on. But now that the radiance of the yuletide season is fading, it's time to confront a sobering scientific truth: The more you think about the biology of parental love, the more absurd it seems. The same goes for love of kin generally--brothers, sisters, nephews, etc.
As modern Darwinism gets popularized, the basic idea of kin selection is approaching the status of conventional wisdom. So are some attendant misconceptions.
Misconception No. 1: Genes are smart .
People often assume that kin-selected altruism is foolproof; that a gene can magically sense copies of itself in other organisms--or, at least, can somehow ascertain with perfect accuracy which organisms are close relatives of its own host organism and thus may carry copies of itself. In truth, genes aren't omniscient, or even sentient. If kin-selected genes are going to induce love of kin, they'll have to determine who qualifies as kin in some pedestrian and probably fallible way.
For example: Back when Loving Bob was 6 years old, if his mother was nursing some infant named Bill and sleeping by its side every night, there's a very good chance that Bill was Bob's sibling. So a gene disposing Bob to love children whom he sees his mother nurturing could spread through the population until everyone obeys the same rule. But this rule would misfire now and then, when a mother is for some reason nurturing a non-offspring. It's just that the misfiring wouldn't happen often enough to greatly dilute the genetic math favoring the gene's proliferation.
Little is known about which rules for identifying kin--"kin-recognition mechanisms"--do operate in our species. But clearly, they are fallible. Even mothers, who you'd think would have a damn

Explanation: The most dangerous part of the trip to the moon for humans is the freefall period. Since the rocketship will be travelling at high speeds through lunar orbit, once it has separated from the booster engine, there is the possibility that the rocketship could experience an unanticipated power failure. Without power, the ship loses thrust and enters into freefall, in which case the ship could lose it's orbit and crash onto the lunar surface, or enter into an orbit around the Earth with no way home.
"(A) Freefall."
"Explanation: The most dangerous part of the trip to the moon for humans is the freefall period. Since the rocketship will be travelling at high speeds through lunar orbit, once it has separated from the booster engine, there is the possibility that the rocketship could experience an unanticipated power failure. Without power, the ship loses thrust and enters into freefall, in which case the ship could lose it's orbit and crash onto the lunar surface, or enter into an orbit around the Earth with no way home." 
The reason why the freefall period presents the greatest risk has to do with the unique circumstances of space flight. Once in outer space, where there is no air pressure to hold them up, objects fall at an accelerating rate due to gravity. In the absence of atmospheric friction and other forces counteracting gravity, it would take just over nine seconds for a free-falling object to reach terminal velocity, over three minutes for an object falling from a position outside the Earth's atmosphere, which is what the ship is doing during this period. To put it simply, even a minor power failure in the ship's systems could result in an unstoppable freefall, which is why this phase of the journey poses the greatest risk of catastrophic events for the crew and passengers.
